message.subtitle: The Roman Republic's Greatest Struggle
message.text:
@G[c3 stills_97.png]@L @H Message @L On the island of Sicily, tensions have boiled over. Roman diplomats were insulted, and colonization efforts were hindered by the Carthaginians living there. This insult to all Romans has caused an outrage in the Senate, and a declaration of war swiftly followed. This conflict will put all Roman cities to the test, as all citizens are expected to contribute to the war effort. @L@L Weapons, denarii, and manpower will need to be sent to fuel the Roman war machine. Your growing city is in a good position to capitalize on these conditions. However, be warned: if you fail to provide the requested supplies, you will not only fall out of favor with the Senate but will also jeopardize the war effort with severe consequences. @L@L @G[decorative objetive .png] @H New Development @L The Senate will now start to request weapons, denarii, and wheat in large amounts. Your favor will naturally decline by an additional -2 per year. @G[weapon_taken.png] @G[decorative objetive .png] @L@L
@H Historical Background @L Since the Carthaginian state was a direct inheritor of the Phoenician culture, their armies fought in a similar manner to the Greek phalanx. Specialist units like mercenary or auxiliary light infantry and cavalry were often included. Slingers from the Balearic Islands were popular as well. Amongst the cavalry, Carthage often employed Numidian light cavalry who excelled at skirmishing and screening. @L@L For infantry, Iberians and Celts would see wide use to boost the ranks of the citizen hoplites. Famously, Carthage was also fond of using war elephants. This did sometimes result in a disaster for the Carthaginians, however, as in the Battle of Zama during the Second Punic War. The 80 war elephants were likely newly captured and only partially trained. @L@L When Romans opened gaps in the line of their infantry, the animals ran into them and were pelted by skirmishers, killing many and driving the rest of them back. The elephants then charged and severely damaged the Carthaginian cavalry which led to Roman superiority and eventual victory. @L@L We previously discussed early Roman military organization with Greek style phalanx. This was no longer in practice even during the Samnite Wars. Instead, around 315 BC the Romans invented the manipular system. This system developed smaller scale units where a maniple would typically be comprised of 120 soldiers arrayed in 3 ranks of 40 men. @L@L This system would also see the creation of the familiar 3-line system and separation into designated units of velites (skirmishers), hastati (young and poor infantry), principes (middle aged wealthier heavy infantry) and triarii (the oldest and most experienced and best equipped infantry). @L@L The echelons differed not only in their roles, but also in their equipment. Polybius describes their panoply in detail. First, the velites were armed with a sword, javelins, and a small shield called a parma. They wore no armor, apart from a helmet which was often covered in animal skins. Polybius asserts that these skins not only protected the helmet, but also served as a means of identification, such that soldiers could be remembered and later rewarded for acts of bravery. Next, the hastati were armed in "full panoply". Their armament included a sword, javelins, and a large, reinforced shield. For armor, they wore a helmet decorated with tall plumes designed to make its wearer appear larger, as well as a sheet of metal called a "heart plate" to protect the chest. Principes were equipped in the same manner as the hastati. Wealthier soldiers (of a property value greater than 10,000 drachmas) could afford a chain mail cuirass. Finally, the triarii were equipped like the other infantry, except for a thrusting spear in place of javelins. @L@L This equipment was generally lighter and cheaper than that of the Servian hoplites that preceded the maniple. It emphasized the flexibility of the maniple system and allowed for lightly armored, highly mobile soldiers. Moreover, because purchasing the equipment was the responsibility of the individual soldier, its affordability helped increase the number of citizens eligible for military service. @L@L Hastati and principes would carry "pila" or throwing javelins to break up enemy charges and to give them the capability to use projectiles in case of a siege of defenses. @L@L Romans would also employ skirmishers and cavalry made up of auxiliary from their Italic allies and later also Celts, Germans, and Greeks as well as various other peoples. @L@L The Roman strategy shifted and relied on tiring the enemy out while holding significant parts of the army, up to 2/3, in reserve. Large shields or scutum would be ideal for defensive tactics and letting the enemy tire themselves out attacking the Romans. When the enemy tired, the Romans would start to push back. @L@L Some historians believe there was a system for rotating out tired units on the frontline, but this is debated, as disengaging would often be difficult. @L@L One reason for adopting the manipular system was also that Rome now found itself fighting Samnites and other hill peoples, who preferred to fight as light infantry in rough terrain and the phalanx had difficulties traversing such terrain effectively. Smaller more flexible units who preferred a line formation were much better used in this environment. @L@L From the new makeup of the Roman legion, heavy infantry was more dominant than ever and thus started to see Romans favoring open pitched battles where armies would advance into each other without much in terms of flanking maneuvers. This also made the Romans develop a strong martial culture and similar mindset. The word for ambush was used interchangeably for lie or dishonor. @L@L Roman strategy also revolved strongly around logistics. To force enemies to give battle and make mistakes, Roman armies in the field would try to remain highly supplied and be able to take defensive position on a hill or in a chokepoint and starve the enemy army into attacking them. Armies at this time often relied predominantly on foraging or trying to live off the land. Romans would send parties to harass the enemy and deprive them of forage, forcing them into a position where they had to attack. @L@L Contrary to popular belief, two armies meeting each other would often not result in an immediate battle. Often you would see skirmishing, harassing of supply lines, and an effort to take better tactical position first, which could sometimes take weeks at a time before the major engagement was fought. @L@L@L@L
